Problem Statement:
Consider a system composed of a very large number $N$ of distinguishable atoms, non-moving and mutually non-interacting, each of which has only two (non-degenerate) energy levels: $0, \varepsilon>0$. Let $E / N$ be the mean energy per atom in the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$.

For thermodynamic equilibrium, compute the entropy per atom, $S / N$, as a function of $E / N$.
Solution:
If the system is not necesssarily in thermodynamic equilibrium, the maximum possible value of $E / N$ is $\varepsilon$; and if the system is in equilibrium (at positive temperature), the maximum possible value of $E / N$ is $\varepsilon / 2$ corresponding to $T \rightarrow \infty$.When the mean energy per atom is $E / N, E / \varepsilon$ particles are on the level of energy $\epsilon$ and the microscopic state number is

$$
Q=\frac{N !}{\left(\frac{E}{\varepsilon}\right) !\left(N-\frac{E}{\epsilon}\right) !}
$$

So the entropy of the system is

$$
S=k \ln \frac{N !}{\left(\frac{E}{\varepsilon}\right) !\left(N-\frac{E}{\varepsilon}\right) !}
$$

If $E / \varepsilon \gg 1, N-E / \varepsilon \gg 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{S}{N} &=k\left[\ln N-\frac{E / \varepsilon}{N} \ln \frac{E}{\varepsilon}-\left(1-\frac{E / \varepsilon}{N}\right) \ln \left(N-\frac{E}{\varepsilon}\right)\right] \\
&=k\left[\frac{E}{\varepsilon N} \ln \frac{\varepsilon N}{E}+\left(1-\frac{E}{N \varepsilon}\right) \ln \frac{1}{1-\frac{E}{\varepsilon N}}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

This corresponds to $N ! /\left(N_{+} ! N_{-} !\right)$arrangements. Note that for every arrangement if the angles are reversed, we still get the overall length of $2 m d$. Thus

$$
g=\frac{2 N !}{\left(\frac{N}{2}+m\right) !\left(\frac{N}{2}-m\right) !}
$$

When $m \ll N, g(N, m) \approx g(N, 0) \exp \left(-2 m^{2} / N\right)$, the entropy of the system becomes

$$

The elasticity of a rubber band can be described in terms of a onedimensional model of polymer involving $N$ molecules linked together endto-end. The angle between successive links is equally likely to be $0^{\circ}$ or $180^{\circ}$

Find the force required to maintain the length $L$ for $L \ll N d$.

$$
\text { Therefore } \begin{array}{ll}

N_{+}=\frac{N}{2}+m, \quad N_{-}=\frac{N}{2}-m .
\end{array}
$$

This corresponds to $N ! /\left(N_{+} ! N_{-} !\right)$arrangements. Note that for every arrangement if the angles are reversed, we still get the overall length of $2 m d$. Thus

$$
g=\frac{2 N !}{\left(\frac{N}{2}+m\right) !\left(\frac{N}{2}-m\right) !}
$$

When $m \ll N, g(N, m) \approx g(N, 0) \exp \left(-2 m^{2} / N\right)$, the entropy of the system becomes

$$
S=k \ln g(N, m)=k \ln g(N, 0)-\frac{k L^{2}}{2 N d^{2}} .
$$From the thermodynamic relations $d U=T d S+f d L$ and $F=$ $U-T S$ we obtain $d F=-S d T+f d L$. Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}

$$

Problem Statement:
Consider an idealization of a crystal which has $N$ lattice points and the same number of interstitial positions (places between the lattice points where atoms can reside). Let $E$ be the energy necessary to remove an atom from a lattice site to an interstitial position and let $n$ be the number of atoms occupying interstitial sites in equilibrium.

What is the entropy $S$ ? Give an asymptotic formula valid when $n \gg 1 ?$
Solution:
Let $U_{0}$ be the internal energy when no atom occupies the interstitial sites. When $n$ interstitial positions are occupied, the internal energy is then

$$
U=U_{0}+n E .
$$There are $C_{n}^{N}$ ways of selecting $n$ atoms from $N$ lattice sites, and $C_{n}^{N}$ ways to place them to $N$ interstitial sites; so the microscopic state number is $\Omega=\left(C_{n}^{N}\right)^{2}$. Hence

$$
S=k \ln \Omega=2 k \ln \frac{N !}{n !(N-n) !} .
$$

When $n \gg 1$ and $(N-n) \gg 1$, we have $\ln (n !)=n \ln n-n$, so that

$$
S=2 k[N \ln N-n \ln n-(N-n) \ln (N-n)] .
$$

Solution:
Let $U_{0}$ be the internal energy when no atom occupies the interstitial sites. When $n$ interstitial positions are occupied, the internal energy is then

$$

Problem Statement:
Energy probability.

Find and make careful sketch of the probability density, $\rho(E)$, for the energy $E$ of a single atom in a classical non-interacting monatomic gas in thermal equilibrium.
Solution:
When the number of gas atoms is very large, we can represent the states of the system by a continuous distribution. When the system reaches thermal equilibrium, the probability of an atom having energy $E$ is proportional to $\exp (-E / k T)$, where $E=p^{2} / 2 m, p$ being the momentum of the atom. So the probability of an atom lying between $\mathbf{p}$ and $\mathbf{p}+d \mathbf{p}$ is

$$
A \exp \left(-p^{2} / 2 m k T\right) d^{3} \mathbf{p} .
$$

From

$$
A \int \exp \left(-p^{2} / 2 m k T\right) d^{3} \mathbf{p}=1 \text {, }
$$

we obtain

$$
A=(2 \pi m k T)^{-3 / 2} .
$$

Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int A e^{-p^{2} / 2 m k T} d^{3} \mathbf{p} &=\frac{2 \pi}{(\pi k T)^{3 / 2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} E^{1 / 2} e^{-E / k T} d E \\
& \equiv \int_{0}^{\infty} \rho(E) d E
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
\rho(E)=\frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}(k T)^{3 / 2}} E^{1 / 2} e^{-E / k T} .
$$

Problem Statement:
A system of two energy levels $E_{0}$ and $E_{1}$ is populated by $N$ particles at temperature $T$. The particles populate the energy levels according to the classical distribution law.

Compute the average energy per particle vs the temperature as $T \rightarrow 0$ and $T \rightarrow \infty$ ticles.
Solution:
The average energy of a particle is

$$
u=\frac{E_{0} e^{-\beta E_{0}}+E_{1} e^{-\beta E_{1}}}{e^{-\beta E_{0}}+e^{-\beta E_{1}}} .
$$

Assuming $E_{1}>E_{0}>0$ and letting $\Delta E=E_{1}-E_{0}$, we have

$$
u=\frac{E_{0}+E_{1} e^{-\beta \Delta E}}{1+e^{-\beta \Delta E}} .
$$

When $T \rightarrow 0$, i.e., $\beta=1 / k T \rightarrow \infty$, one has

$$
u \approx\left(E_{0}+E_{1} e^{-\beta \Delta E}\right)\left(1-e^{-\beta \Delta E}\right)=E_{0}+\Delta E e^{-\beta \Delta E} .
$$

When $T \rightarrow \infty$, or $\beta \rightarrow 0$, one has

$$
u \approx \frac{1}{2}\left(E_{0}+E_{1}-\beta E_{1} \Delta E\right)\left(1+\frac{1}{2} \beta \Delta E\right) \approx \frac{1}{2}\left(E_{0}+E_{1}\right)-\frac{\beta}{4}(\Delta E)^{2} .
$$

Problem Statement:
A system of two energy levels $E_{0}$ and $E_{1}$ is populated by $N$ particles at temperature $T$. The particles populate the energy levels according to the classical distribution law.

Compute the specific heat in the limits $T \rightarrow 0$ and $T \rightarrow \infty$.
Solution:
The average energy of a particle is

$$
u=\frac{E_{0} e^{-\beta E_{0}}+E_{1} e^{-\beta E_{1}}}{e^{-\beta E_{0}}+e^{-\beta E_{1}}} .
$$

Assuming $E_{1}>E_{0}>0$ and letting $\Delta E=E_{1}-E_{0}$, we have

$$
u=\frac{E_{0}+E_{1} e^{-\beta \Delta E}}{1+e^{-\beta \Delta E}} .
$$

When $T \rightarrow 0$, i.e., $\beta=1 / k T \rightarrow \infty$, one has

$$
u \approx\left(E_{0}+E_{1} e^{-\beta \Delta E}\right)\left(1-e^{-\beta \Delta E}\right)=E_{0}+\Delta E e^{-\beta \Delta E} .
$$

When $T \rightarrow \infty$, or $\beta \rightarrow 0$, one has

$$
u \approx \frac{1}{2}\left(E_{0}+E_{1}-\beta E_{1} \Delta E\right)\left(1+\frac{1}{2} \beta \Delta E\right) \approx \frac{1}{2}\left(E_{0}+E_{1}\right)-\frac{\beta}{4}(\Delta E)^{2} .
$$The specific heat (per mole) is

$$
C=N_{A} \frac{\partial u}{\partial T}=N_{A} \frac{\partial u}{\partial \beta} \cdot \frac{\partial \beta}{\partial T}=R\left(\frac{\Delta E}{k T}\right)^{2} \frac{e^{-\Delta E / k T}}{\left(1+e^{-\Delta E / k T}\right)^{2}} .
$$

When $T \rightarrow 0$, one has

$$
C \approx R \cdot\left(\frac{\Delta E}{k T}\right)^{2} \cdot e^{-\Delta E / k T} .
$$

When $T \rightarrow \infty$

$$
C \approx \frac{R}{4} \cdot\left(\frac{\Delta E}{k T}\right)^{2} .
$$
Final Answer: $$R\left(\frac{\Delta E}{k T}\right)^{2} \frac{e^{-\Delta E / k T}}{\left(1+e^{-\Delta E / k T}\right)^{2}}$$

Problem Statement:
Consider a glass in which some fraction of its constituent atoms may occupy either of two slightly different positions giving rise to two energy levels $\Delta_{i}>0$ and $-\Delta_{i}$ for the $i$ th atom.

If each participating atom has the same levels $\Delta$ and $-\Delta$, calculate the contribution of these atoms to the heat capacity.
(Definite integrals need not be evaluated provided they do not depend on any of the parameters.)
Solution:
The mean energy per atom is $\bar{\varepsilon}=\Delta \tanh \left(\frac{\Delta}{k T}\right)$. Its contribution to the specific heat is

$$
c_{v}=\frac{d \bar{\varepsilon}}{d T}=4 k\left(\frac{\Delta}{k T}\right)^{2} \frac{1}{\left(e^{\Delta / k T}+e^{-\Delta / k T}\right)^{2}} .
$$

Summing up the terms for all such atoms, we have

$$
c_{v}=4 N k\left(\frac{\Delta}{k T}\right)^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{\left(e^{\Delta / k T}+e^{-\Delta / k T}\right)^{2}} .
$$
Final Answer: $$4 N k\left(\frac{\Delta}{k T}\right)^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{\left(e^{\Delta / k T}+e^{-\Delta / k T}\right)^{2}}$$

Consider a glass in which some fraction of its constituent atoms may occupy either of two slightly different positions giving rise to two energy levels $\Delta_{i}>0$ and $-\Delta_{i}$ for the $i$ th atom.

If the glass has a random composition of such atoms so that all values of $\Delta_{i}$ are equally likely up to some limiting value $\Delta_{0}>0$, find the behavior of the low temperature heat capacity, i.e., $k T \ll \Delta_{0}$.
(Definite integrals need not be evaluated provided they do not depend on any of the parameters.)
Solution:
The mean energy per atom is $\bar{\varepsilon}=\Delta \tanh \left(\frac{\Delta}{k T}\right)$. Its contribution to the specific heat is

$$
c_{v}=\frac{d \bar{\varepsilon}}{d T}=4 k\left(\frac{\Delta}{k T}\right)^{2} \frac{1}{\left(e^{\Delta / k T}+e^{-\Delta / k T}\right)^{2}} .
$$

Summing up the terms for all such atoms, we have

$$
c_{v}=4 N k\left(\frac{\Delta}{k T}\right)^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{\left(e^{\Delta / k T}+e^{-\Delta / k T}\right)^{2}} .
$$The contribution to the specific heat of the $i$ th atom is

$$
c_{i}=4 k\left(\frac{\Delta_{i}}{k T}\right)^{2} \frac{1}{\left(e^{\Delta_{i} / k T}+e^{-\Delta_{i} / k T}\right)^{2}} .
$$

$$

$$
\begin{aligned}

Problem Statement: The three lowest energy levels of a certain molecule are $E_{1}=0, E_{2}=$ $\varepsilon, E_{3}=10 \varepsilon$. Show that at sufficiently low temperatures (how low?) only levels $E_{1}, E_{2}$ are populated. Find the average energy $E$ of the molecule at temperature $T$. Find the contributions of these levels to the specific heat per mole, $C_{v}$, and sketch $C_{v}$ as a function of $T$.
Solution:
We need not consider energy levels higher than the three lowest energy levels for low temperatures. Assuming the system has $N$ particles and according to the Boltzmann statistics, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&N_{1}+N_{2}+N_{3}=N, \\
&\frac{N_{2}}{N_{1}}=e^{-\varepsilon / k T}, \\
&\frac{N_{3}}{N_{1}}=e^{-10 \boldsymbol{\varepsilon} / k T},
\end{aligned}
$$

hence

$$
N_{3}=\frac{N}{1+e^{9 \varepsilon / k T}+e^{10 \epsilon / k T}} .
$$

When $N_{3}<1$, there is no occupation at the energy level $E_{3}$. That is, when $T<T_{c}$, only the $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ levels are occupied, where $T_{c}$ satisfies

$$
\frac{N}{1+e^{9 \epsilon / k T_{c}}+e^{10 \epsilon / k T_{c}}}=1 .
$$

If $N \gg 1$, we have

$$
T_{c} \approx \frac{10 \varepsilon}{k \ln N} .
$$

The average energy of the molecule is

$$
E=\frac{\varepsilon\left(e^{-\epsilon / k T}+10 e^{-10 \epsilon / k T}\right)}{1+e^{-\epsilon / k T}+e^{-10 \epsilon / k T}} .
$$

The molar specific heat is

$$
C_{v}=N_{A} \frac{\partial E}{\partial T}=\frac{R \varepsilon^{2}\left(e^{-\beta \varepsilon}+100 e^{-10 \beta \boldsymbol{\epsilon}}+81 e^{-11 \beta \varepsilon}\right)}{\left(1+e^{-\beta \boldsymbol{\varepsilon}}+e^{-10 \beta \varepsilon}\right)^{2}} \beta^{2},
$$

where $\beta=1 / k T$ and $N_{A}$ is Avogadro's number.

For high temperatures, $k T \gg \varepsilon$,

$$
C_{v} \approx \frac{182}{9} R\left(\frac{\varepsilon}{k T}\right)^{2} \propto \frac{1}{T^{2}} .
$$

For low temperatures, $k T \ll \varepsilon$,

$$
C_{v} \approx R \varepsilon^{2} \frac{e^{-\epsilon / k T}}{(k T)^{2}} .
$$

Problem Statement: Given a system of two distinct lattice sites, each occupied by an atom whose spin $(s=1)$ is so oriented that its energy takes one of three values $\varepsilon=1,0,-1$ with equal probability. The atoms do not interact with each other. Calculate the ensemble average values $\bar{U}$ and $\bar{U}^{2}$ for the energy $U$ of the system, assumed to be that of the spins only.
Solution:
For a single atom, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\bar{\varepsilon}=-\frac{e^{\beta}-e^{-\beta}}{1+e^{\beta}+e^{-\beta}}, \\
&\overline{\varepsilon^{2}}=\frac{e^{\beta}+e^{-\beta}}{1+e^{\beta}+e^{-\beta}}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the system, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\bar{U}=\bar{\varepsilon}_{1}+\bar{\varepsilon}_{2}=-2 \frac{e^{\beta}-e^{-\beta}}{1+e^{\beta}+e^{-\beta}}, \\
&\overline{U^{2}}=\overline{\left(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2}\right)^{2}}=\overline{\varepsilon_{1}^{2}}+\overline{\varepsilon_{2}^{2}}+\overline{2 \varepsilon_{1} \varepsilon_{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\overline{\varepsilon_{1} \varepsilon_{2}}=\overline{\varepsilon_{1}} \cdot \overline{\varepsilon_{2}}$, it follows

$$
\overline{U^{2}}=\frac{2[\exp (2 \beta)+\exp (-2 \beta)+\exp (\beta)+\exp (-\beta)]}{(1+\exp (\beta)+\exp (-\beta))^{2}} .
$$

Problem Statement:
Assume that the reaction $\mathrm{H} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{p}+\mathrm{e}$ occurs in thermal equilibrium at $T=4000 \mathrm{~K}$ in a very low density gas (no degeneracy) of each species with overall charge neutrality.

Give the condition for thermal equilibrium and calculate the equilibrium value of $[\mathrm{e}]$ as a function of $[\mathrm{H}]$ and $T$.
(Note that this is an approximate picture of the universe at a redshift $z=10^{3}$.)
Solution:
From Boltzmann statistics, we have for an ideal gas without spin

$$
n=e^{\mu / k T} \cdot\left(2 \pi m k T / h^{2}\right)^{3 / 2} .
$$

Both the proton and electron have spin $1 / 2$, therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{[\mathrm{p}]=2\left(2 \pi m_{\mathrm{p}} k T / h^{2}\right)^{3 / 2} e^{\mu_{\mathrm{p}} / k T}} \\
&{[\mathrm{e}]=2\left(2 \pi m_{\mathrm{e}} k T / h^{2}\right)^{3 / 2} e^{\mu_{\mathrm{e}} / k T} .}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the hydrogen atom, $\mathrm{p}$ and e can form four spin configurations with ionization energy $E_{d}$. Hence

$$
[\mathrm{H}]=4\left(2 \pi m_{\mathrm{H}} k T / h^{2}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left(E_{d} / k T\right) \exp \left(\mu_{\mathrm{H}} / k T\right) .
$$

The chemical potentials $\mu_{\mathrm{p}}, \mu_{\mathrm{e}}$ and $\mu_{\mathrm{H}}$ are given by the above relations with the number densities.

The equilibrium condition is $\mu_{\mathrm{H}}=\mu_{\mathrm{e}}+\mu_{\mathrm{p}}$. Note that as $m_{\mathrm{H}} \approx m_{\mathrm{p}}$ and $[\mathrm{e}]=[\mathrm{p}]$ we have

$$
[\mathbf{e}]=\sqrt{[\mathrm{H}]} \cdot\left(2 \pi m_{\mathrm{e}} k T / h^{2}\right)^{3 / 2} \cdot \exp \left(-E_{d} / 2 k T\right) .
$$
Final Answer: $$\sqrt{[\mathrm{H}]} \cdot\left(2 \pi m_{\mathrm{e}} k T / h^{2}\right)^{3 / 2} \cdot \exp \left(-E_{d} / 2 k T\right)$$

Problem Statement:
A piece of metal can be considered as a reservoir of electrons; the work function (energy to remove an electron from the metal) is $4 \mathrm{eV}$. Give only one significant figure. and $\mathrm{H}^{-}$?

What value of the work function would give equal probabilities to $\mathrm{H}^{0}$
Solution:
We have (see Fig. 2.8)

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathrm{e}+\mathrm{H}^{+} \leftrightarrows \mathrm{H}, \\
&\mathrm{e}+\mathrm{H} \leftrightarrows \mathrm{H}^{-} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Fig. 2.8.

The chemical potential of the electron gas is $\mu_{\mathrm{e}}=-W$. From classical statistics, we can easily obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{[\mathrm{e}]=2 e^{\mu_{\mathrm{e}} / k T}\left(\frac{2 \pi m_{\mathrm{e}} k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2}} \\
&{\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]=2 e^{\mu_{\mathrm{H}}+/ k T}\left(\frac{2 \pi m_{\mathrm{p}} k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the factor 2 arises from the internal degrees of freedom of spin. For the hydrogen atom, electron and proton spins can have four possible spin states, hence

$$
\left[\mathrm{H}^{0}\right]=4 e^{\mu_{\mathrm{H}^{0}} / k T}\left(\frac{2 \pi m_{\mathrm{p}} k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} e^{\boldsymbol{c}_{1} / k T} .

$$
\left[\mathrm{H}^{-}\right]=2 e^{\mu_{\mathrm{H}^{-}} / k T}\left(\frac{2 \pi m_{\mathrm{p}} k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left(\frac{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2}}{k T}\right) .
$$

The conditions for chemical equilibrium are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mu_{\mathrm{H}^{0}}=\mu_{\mathrm{e}}+\mu_{\mathrm{H}^{+}}, \\
&\mu_{\mathrm{H}^{-}}=\mu_{\mathrm{e}}+\mu_{\mathrm{H}^{0}},
\end{aligned}
$$

so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\left[\mathrm{H}^{0}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]}=2 \exp \frac{\mu_{\mathrm{e}}+\varepsilon_{1}}{k T}, \\
&\frac{\left[\mathrm{H}^{-}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{H}^{0}\right]}=\frac{1}{2} \exp \frac{\mu_{\mathrm{e}}+\varepsilon_{2}}{k T} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the relative probabilities of finding $\mathrm{H}^{+}, \mathrm{H}^{0}$ and $\mathrm{H}^{-}$are

$$
\begin{gathered}

\exp \frac{2 \mu_{\mathrm{e}}+\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2}}{k T}=1: 2 e^{371}: e^{240}
\end{gathered}
$$

If $P_{\mathrm{H}}=P_{\mathrm{H}-}$, or $\left[\mathrm{H}^{0}\right]=\left[\mathrm{H}^{-}\right]$, we have

$$
W=-\mu_{\mathrm{e}}=-\varepsilon_{2}+k T \ln 2 \approx 0.6 \mathrm{eV} .
$$

Problem Statement:
Consider a system of $N_{0}$ non-interacting quantum mechanical oscillators in equilibrium at temperature $T$. The energy levels of a single oscillator are

$$
E_{m}=(m+1 / 2) \gamma / V \quad \text { with } m=0,1,2 \ldots \text { etc. }
$$

( $\gamma$ is a constant, the oscillators and volume $V$ are one dimensional.)

Find $U$ and $C_{v}$ as functions of $T$.
Solution:
The partition function is

$$
\begin{aligned}
z &=\sum_{m=0}^{\infty} e^{-\beta(m+1 / 2) \gamma V^{-1}}=\frac{e^{-\left(\beta \gamma V^{-1 / 2}\right)}}{1-e^{-\beta \gamma V^{-1}}} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{csch} \frac{\gamma \beta}{2 V} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The internal energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
U &=-N_{0} \frac{\partial}{\partial \beta} \ln z=\frac{N_{0} \gamma}{2 V} \operatorname{coth} \frac{\gamma \beta}{2 V} \\
&=\frac{N_{0} \gamma}{2 V} \operatorname{coth} \frac{\gamma}{2 V k T} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The specific heat at constant volume is

$$
c_{v}=\left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial T}\right)_{v}=N_{0} k\left(\frac{\gamma}{2 V k T}\right)^{2} \operatorname{csch}^{2}\left(\frac{\gamma}{2 V k T}\right) .
$$
Final Answer: $$N_{0} k\left(\frac{\gamma}{2 V k T}\right)^{2} \operatorname{csch}^{2}\left(\frac{\gamma}{2 V k T}\right)$$

Problem Statement:
The quantum energy levels of a rigid rotator are

$$
\varepsilon_{j}=j(j+1) h^{2} / 8 \pi^{2} m a^{2},
$$

where $j=0,1,2, \ldots \quad$ The degeneracy of each level is $g_{j}=2 j+1$.

Evaluate the high-temperature energy and heat capacity.
Solution:
The partition function is

$$
z=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty} g_{j} e^{-\epsilon, / k T}=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}(2 j+1) e^{-j(j+1) h^{2} / 8 \pi^{2} m a^{2} k T} .
$$At high temperatures $\Delta_{x} \equiv\left(h^{2} / 8 \pi^{2} m a^{2} k T\right)^{1 / 2} \ll 1$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
z &=2 e^{h^{2} / 32 \pi^{2} m a^{2} k T} \sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\left(j+\frac{1}{2}\right) e^{-(j+1 / 2)^{2} h^{2} / 8 \pi^{2} m a^{2} k T} \\
&=2 e^{\left(\Delta_{x}\right)^{2} / 4} \frac{1}{\left(\Delta_{x}\right)^{2}} \sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \varepsilon_{j} e^{-\varepsilon_{j}^{2}} \Delta \varepsilon_{j},
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\varepsilon_{j}=\left(j+\frac{1}{2}\right) \Delta_{x}, \Delta \varepsilon_{j}=\varepsilon_{j+1}-\varepsilon_{j}=\Delta_{x} .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
z & \approx \frac{2}{\left(\Delta_{x}\right)^{2}} e^{\left(\Delta_{x}\right)^{2} / 4} \int_{0}^{\infty} \varepsilon e^{-\epsilon^{2}} d \varepsilon=\frac{1}{\left(\Delta_{x}\right)^{2}} e^{\left(\Delta_{x}\right)^{2} / 4} \\
& \approx\left(\Delta_{x}\right)=8 \pi^{2} m a^{2} k T / h^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The internal energy is

$$
U=k T^{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial T} \ln z=k T .
$$

The heat capacity is

$$
C_{v}=\frac{\partial U}{\partial T}=k .
$$

Problem Statement:

Problem Statement:

For a classical rotator, one has

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E=\frac{1}{2 I}\left(p_{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \theta} p_{\varphi}^{2}\right), \\
&z=\int e^{-\beta E} d p_{\theta} d p_{\varphi} d \theta d \varphi=\frac{8 \pi^{2} I}{\beta}, \\
&\langle E\rangle=-\frac{\partial}{\partial \beta} \ln z=\frac{1}{\beta}=k T,
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $C(T)=k$.In quantum statistical mechanics,

$$
\begin{aligned}
z &=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}(2 j+1) \exp \left[-\frac{\beta \hbar^{2}}{2 I} j(j+1)\right] \\
\langle E\rangle &=-\frac{1}{z} \frac{\partial z}{\partial \beta} \\

\end{aligned}
$$In the limit of low temperatures, $\frac{\beta \hbar}{2 I} \gg 1$, or $\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2} \bar{I} \gg k T$, so only the first two terms $j=0$ and $j=1$ are important. Thus

$$
\begin{gathered}
z=1+3 \exp \left(-\frac{\beta \hbar^{2}}{I}\right) . \\

\end{gathered}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}

\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{gathered}

Problem Statement:
A gas of molecular hydrogen $\mathrm{H}_{2}$, is originally in equilibrium at a temperature of $1,000 \mathrm{~K}$. It is cooled to $20 \mathrm{~K}$ so quickly that the nuclear spin states of the molecules do not change, although the translational and rotational degrees of freedom do readjust through collisions. What is the approximate internal energy per molecule in terms of temperature units $\mathrm{K}$ ?

Note that the rotational part of the energy for a diatomic molecule is $A l(l+1)$ where $l$ is the rotational quantum number and $A \sim 90 \mathrm{~K}$ for $\mathrm{H}_{2}$. Vibrational motion can be neglected.
Solution:
Originally the temperature is high and the para- and orthohydrogen molecules are in equilibrium in a ratio of about $1: 3$. When the system is quickly cooled, for a rather long period the nuclear spin states remain the same. The ratio of parahydrogen to orthohydrogen is still $1: 3$. Now the para- and orthohydrogen are no longer in equilibrium but, through collisions, each component is in equilibrium by itself. At the low temperature of $20 \mathrm{~K}$, $\exp (-\beta A) \sim \exp (-90 / 20) \ll 1$, so that each is in its ground state. Thus $\bar{E}_{r, \mathrm{p}}=0, \bar{E}_{\mathrm{r}, \mathrm{o}}=A(1+1) \cdot 1=2 A=180 \mathrm{~K}$, giving

$$
\bar{E}_{\mathrm{r}}=\frac{1}{4} \bar{E}_{\mathrm{r}, \mathrm{p}}+\frac{3}{4} \bar{E}_{\mathrm{r}, \mathrm{O}}=135 \mathrm{~K} .
$$

From equipartition of energy, we have

$$
\bar{E}_{\mathrm{t}}=\frac{3}{2} k T=30 \mathrm{~K} .
$$

The average energy of a molecule is

$$
\bar{E}=\bar{E}_{\mathrm{t}}+\bar{E}_{\mathrm{r}}=165 \mathrm{~K} .
$$

Problem Statement: A ${ }^{7} \mathrm{~N}_{14}$ nucleus has nuclear spin $I=1$. Assume that the diatomic molecule $\mathrm{N}_{2}$ can rotate but does not vibrate at ordinary temperatures and ignore electronic motion. Find the relative abundances of the ortho- and para-molecules in a sample of nitrogen gas. (Ortho = symmetric spin state; Para $=$ antisymmetric spin state). What happens to the relative abundance as the temperature is lowered towards absolute zero? (Justify your answers!)
Solution:
The wave function of $N_{2}$ is symmetric as ${ }^{7} \mathrm{~N}_{14}$ is a boson. The spin wave functions of $\mathrm{N}_{2}$ consist of six symmetric and three antisymmetric functions. We know that the rotating wave function is symmetric when the spin wave function is symmetric, and the rotating wavefunction is antisymmetric when the spin wave function is antisymmetric. Hence, the partition function of ortho- $\mathrm{N}_{2}$ is

$$
Z_{\text {ortho }}=\sum_{l=0,2,4, \ldots}^{\infty} 6(2 l+1) e^{-\theta, l(l+1) / T},
$$

where $\theta_{r}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 k T}$, and $I$ is the rotational moment of inertia of $\mathrm{N}_{2}$. Similarly,

$$
Z_{\mathrm{para}}=\sum_{l=1,3,5, \ldots} 3(2 l+1) e^{-\theta \cdot l(l+1) / T} .
$$

As $\theta_{r} / T \ll 1$ at ordinary temperatures, the sums can be replaced by integrals:

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z_{\text {ortho }} &=3 \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\theta_{r} x / T} d x=\frac{3 T}{\theta_{r}} \\
Z_{\text {para }} &=1.5 \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\theta_{r} x / T} d x=\frac{3 T}{2 \theta_{r}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the relative abundance is given by

$$
\frac{N_{\text {ortho }}}{N_{\text {para }}}=\frac{Z_{\text {ortho }} e^{\beta \mu_{\text {ortho }}}}{Z_{\text {para }} e^{\beta \mu_{\text {para }}}} .
$$

At equilibrium, $\mu_{\text {ortho }}=\mu_{\text {para }}$, the above ratio is 2 .

When the temperature is lowered towards the absolute zero, we have $\left.\theta_{r} / T \gg 1, \exp \mid-\theta_{r} l(l+1) / T\right] \ll 1$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
&Z_{\text {ortho }} \approx 6, \\
&Z_{\text {para }} \approx 9 \exp \left(-2 \theta_{r} / T\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The relative abundance is

$$
\frac{N_{\text {ortho }}}{N_{\text {para }}}=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right) \exp \left(2 \theta_{r} / T\right) .
$$

When $T \rightarrow 0$, the relative abundance $\rightarrow \infty$. All the para-molecules become ortho-molecules.

Problem Statement: Assume the earth's atmosphere is pure nitrogen in thermodynamic equilibrium at a temperature of $300 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the height above sea-level at which the density of the atmosphere is one half its sea-level value.
Solution:
The Maxwell-Boltzmann energy distribution law: For a system of gas in equilibrium, the number of particles whose coordinates are between $\mathbf{r}$ and $\mathbf{r}+d \mathbf{r}$ and whose velocities are between $\mathbf{v}$ and $\mathbf{v}+d \mathbf{v}$ is

$$
d N=n_{0}\left(\frac{m}{2 \pi k T}\right)^{3 / 2} e^{-\varepsilon / k T} d \mathbf{v} d \mathbf{r},
$$

where $n_{0}$ denotes the number of particles in a unit volume for which the potential energy $\varepsilon_{p}$ is zero, $\varepsilon=\varepsilon_{k}+\varepsilon_{p}$ is the total energy, $d \mathbf{v}=d v_{x} d v_{y} d v_{z}$, $d \mathbf{r}=d x d y d z$

The MB distribution is a very general law. It is valid for localized systems, classical systems and non-degenerate quantum systems. It does not hold for degenerate non-localized quantum systems, e.g., a system of electrons of spin $1 / 2$ at a low temperature and of high density.

We choose the $z$-axis perpendicular to the sea level and $z=0$ at the sea level. According to the MB distribution law, the number of molecules in volume element $d x d y d z$ at height $z$ is $d N^{\prime}=n_{0} e^{-m g z / k T} d x d y d z$. Then the number of molecules per unit volume at height $z$ is

$$
n(z)=n_{0} e^{-m g z / k T} .
$$

Thus

$$
z=\frac{k T}{m g} \ln \frac{n_{0}}{n}=\frac{R T}{\mu g} \ln \frac{n_{0}}{n} .
$$

The molecular weight of the nitrogen gas is $\mu=28 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{mol}$. With $g=$ $9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}, R=8.31 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{K}$.mole, $T=300 \mathrm{~K}$, we find $z=6297 \mathrm{~m}$ for $n_{0} / n=2$. That is, the density of the atmosphere at the height $6297 \mathrm{~m}$ is one-half the sea level value.

Problem Statement:
Find the particle density as a function of radial position for a gas of $N$ molecules, each of mass $M$, contained in a centrifuge of radius $R$ and length $L$ rotating with angular velocity $\omega$ about its axis. Neglect the effect of gravity and assume that the centrifuge has been rotating long enough for the gas particles to reach equilibrium.

Fig. $2.13$.
Solution:
In the rest system $S$, the energy $E$ is independent of the radial distance $r$. But in the rotational system $S^{\prime}$, the energy of a particle is

$$
E(r)=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}=\frac{1}{2} M r^{2} \omega^{2} .
$$

The effect of rotation is the same as that of an additional external field acting on the system of

$$
U(r J)=-\frac{1}{2} M r^{2} \omega^{2} .
$$

Using the Boltzmann distribution we get the particle number density

$$
n(r)=A \exp \left(-\frac{U(r)}{k T}\right)=A \exp \left(\frac{M \omega^{2} r^{2}}{2 k T}\right)
$$

where the normalization factor $A$ can be determined by $\int n(r J) d V=N$, giving

$$
A=\frac{N Q}{\pi L\left[e^{Q R^{2}}-1\right]}, \quad \text { with } \quad Q=\frac{M \omega^{2}}{2 k T} .
$$

Thus we have

$$
n(r)=\frac{N M \omega^{2}}{2 \pi k T L} \frac{\exp \left(\frac{M \omega^{2} r^{2}}{2 k T}\right)}{\exp \left(\frac{M \omega^{2} R^{2}}{2 k T}\right)-1} .
$$
Final Answer: $$\frac{N M \omega^{2}}{2 \pi k T L} \frac{\exp \left(\frac{M \omega^{2} r^{2}}{2 k T}\right)}{\exp \left(\frac{M \omega^{2} R^{2}}{2 k T}\right)-1}$$

Find the temperature at which the positron density is $1 / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$. Find the temperature at which it is $10^{10} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$.
Solution:
For $k T / m_{e} c^{2} \ll 1$, nuclear reactions may be neglected. From charge conservation, we have $n_{-}=n_{p}+n_{+}$, where $n_{-}, n_{+}$are the number densities of electrons and positrons respectively. For a non-relativistic nondegenerate case, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&n_{-}=2\left(\frac{2 \pi m_{\mathrm{e}} k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left(\frac{\mu_{-}-m_{\mathrm{e}} c^{2}}{k T}\right), \\
&n_{+}=2\left(\frac{2 \pi m_{\mathrm{e}} k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left(\frac{\mu_{+}-m_{\mathrm{e}} c^{2}}{k T}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mu_{-}$and $\mu_{+}$are the chemical potentials of electrons and positrons respectively. From the chemical equilibrium condition, we obtain $\mu_{-}=$ $-\mu_{+}=\mu$. Hence

$$
n_{+} / n_{-}=\exp (-2 \mu / k T) \text {. }
$$

For $n_{+}=1 / \mathrm{cm}^{3}, n_{-} \approx n_{\mathrm{p}}=10^{10} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$, we have $\exp (\mu / k T)=10^{5}$ or $\mu / k T \approx 11.5$. Substituting these results into the expression of $n_{-}$, we have $T \approx 1.2 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~K}$, so $\mu \approx 1.6 \times 10^{-7}$ erg. For $n=10^{10} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}, \exp (\mu / k T)=\sqrt{2}$, $\mu / k T \approx 0.4$. Substituting these results into the expression of $n_{+}$, we get $T \approx 1.5 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~K}, \mu \approx 8.4 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{erg}$.

Problem Statement:
Consider a gas of spin $1 / 2$ atoms with density $n$ atoms per unit volume. Each atom has intrinsic magnetic moment $\mu$ and the interaction between atoms is negligible.

Assume that the system obeys classical statistics.

What is the probability of finding an atom with $\boldsymbol{\mu}$ parallel to the applied magnetic field $\mathbf{H}$ at absolute temperature $T$ ? With $\boldsymbol{\mu}$ anti-parallel to $\mathbf{H}$ ?
Solution:
The interaction energy between an atom and the external magnetic field is $\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{H}$. By classical Boltzmann distribution, the number of atoms per unit volume in the solid angle element $d \Omega$ in the direction $(\theta, \varphi)$, is

$$
g \exp (-\beta \varepsilon) d \Omega=g \exp (\mu H \cos \theta / k T) d \Omega,
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle between $\boldsymbol{\mu}$ and $\mathbf{H}$ and $g$ is the normalization factor given by

$$
2 \pi g \int_{0}^{\pi} e^{-\beta \epsilon} \sin \theta d \theta=n,
$$

i.e.,

$$
g=\frac{n \mu H}{4 \pi k T \sinh \frac{\mu H}{k T}} .
$$

Hence the probability density for the magnetic moment of an atom to be parallel to $\mathbf{H}$ is

$$
\frac{g}{n} e^{\mu H / k T}=\frac{1}{4 \pi}\left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right) e^{\mu H / k T} / \sinh \left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right) .
$$

and that for the magnetic moment to be antiparallel to $\mathbf{H}$ is

$$
\frac{g}{n} e^{-\mu H / k T}=\frac{1}{4 \pi}\left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right) e^{-\mu H / k T} / \sinh \left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right) .
$$
Final Answer: $$\frac{1}{4 \pi}\left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right) e^{-\mu H / k T} / \sinh \left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right)$$

Problem Statement:
Consider a gas of spin $1 / 2$ atoms with density $n$ atoms per unit volume. Each atom has intrinsic magnetic moment $\mu$ and the interaction between atoms is negligible.

Assume that the system obeys classical statistics.

Find the mean magnetization of the gas in both the high and low temperature limits?
Solution:
The interaction energy between an atom and the external magnetic field is $\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{H}$. By classical Boltzmann distribution, the number of atoms per unit volume in the solid angle element $d \Omega$ in the direction $(\theta, \varphi)$, is

$$
g \exp (-\beta \varepsilon) d \Omega=g \exp (\mu H \cos \theta / k T) d \Omega,
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle between $\boldsymbol{\mu}$ and $\mathbf{H}$ and $g$ is the normalization factor given by

$$
2 \pi g \int_{0}^{\pi} e^{-\beta \epsilon} \sin \theta d \theta=n,
$$

i.e.,

$$
g=\frac{n \mu H}{4 \pi k T \sinh \frac{\mu H}{k T}} .
$$

Hence the probability density for the magnetic moment of an atom to be parallel to $\mathbf{H}$ is

$$
\frac{g}{n} e^{\mu H / k T}=\frac{1}{4 \pi}\left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right) e^{\mu H / k T} / \sinh \left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right) .
$$

and that for the magnetic moment to be antiparallel to $\mathbf{H}$ is

$$
\frac{g}{n} e^{-\mu H / k T}=\frac{1}{4 \pi}\left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right) e^{-\mu H / k T} / \sinh \left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right) .
$$The average magnetization of the gas at temperature $T$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{M} &=2 \pi g \int_{0}^{\pi} e^{\mu H \cos \theta / k T} \mu \cos \theta \sin \theta d \theta \\
&=n \mu\left[\operatorname{coth}\left(\frac{\mu H}{k T}\right)-\frac{k T}{\mu H}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

At high temperatures, $\frac{\mu H}{k T} \ll 1$. Let $\frac{\mu H}{k T}=x$, and expand

$$
\operatorname{coth} x-\frac{1}{x}=\frac{1}{x}\left(1+\frac{x^{2}}{3}-\frac{x^{4}}{45}+\ldots\right)-\frac{1}{x} \approx \frac{1}{3} x .
$$

so $\bar{M} \approx \frac{n \mu^{2}}{3 k T} H$.

At low temperatures, $x \gg 1$, then

$$
\operatorname{coth} x-\frac{1}{x} \approx 1 .
$$

and $\bar{M} \approx n \mu$.

Problem Statement:
Two dipoles, with dipole moments $\mathbf{M}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{M}_{2}$, are held apart at a separation $R$, only the orientations of the moments being free. They are in thermal equilibrium with the environment at temperature $T$. Compute the mean force $\mathbf{F}$ between the dipoles for the high temperature limit $\frac{M_{1} M_{2}}{k T R^{3}} \ll$ 1. The system is to be treated classically.

Remark: The potential energy between two dipoles is:

$$
\phi=\frac{\left(3\left(\mathbf{M}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{R}\right)\left(\mathbf{M}_{2} \cdot \mathbf{R}\right)-\left(\mathbf{M}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{M}_{2}\right) R^{2}\right)}{R^{5}} .
$$
Solution:
Taking the $z$-axis along the line connecting $M_{1}$ and $M_{2}$, we have

$$
\phi=\frac{M_{1} M_{2}}{R^{3}}\left[2 \cos \theta_{1} \cos \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1} \sin \theta_{2} \cos \left(\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}\right)\right]
$$

The classical partition function is

$$
\begin{aligned}
z=& \int e^{-\beta \phi} d \Omega_{1} d \Omega_{2} \\
=& \int \exp \left[-\frac{\beta M_{1} M_{2}}{R^{3}}\right.\\
&\left.\left(2 \cos \theta_{1} \cos \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1} \sin \theta_{2} \cos \left(\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}\right)\right)\right] d \Omega_{1} d \Omega_{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\lambda=\beta M_{1} M_{2} / R^{3} \ll 1$, expanding the integrand with respect to $\lambda$, retaining only the first non-zero terms, and noting that the integral of a linear term of $\cos \theta$ is zero, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
z &=\int\left[1+\frac{\lambda^{2}}{2}\left(2 \cos \theta_{1} \cos \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1} \sin \theta_{2} \cos \left(\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}\right)\right)^{2}\right] d \Omega_{1} d \Omega_{2} \\
&=16 \pi^{2}+\frac{32 \pi^{2}}{9} \lambda^{2}+\frac{4 \pi^{2}}{9}=\frac{4 \pi^{2}}{9}\left(37+8 \lambda^{2}\right), \\
u &=-\frac{1}{z} \frac{\partial z}{\partial \beta}=\frac{16 \lambda}{37+8 \lambda^{2}} \cdot \frac{M_{1} M_{2}}{R^{3}}, \\
F &=-\frac{\partial \dot{u}}{\partial R}=\frac{16 k T}{R} \cdot \frac{74 \lambda^{2}}{37+8 \lambda^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
The molecule of a perfect gas consists of two atoms, of mass $m$, rigidly separated by a distance $d$. The atoms of each molecule carry charges $q$ and $-q$ respectively, and the gas is placed in an electric field $\varepsilon$. Find the mean polarization, and the specific heat per molecule, if quantum effects can be neglected.

State the condition for this last assumption to be true.
Solution:
Assume that the angle between a molecular dipole and the external field is $\theta$. The energy of a dipole in the field is

$$
E=-E_{0} \cos \theta, E_{0}=d q \varepsilon .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{p}=\frac{\int d q \cos \theta e^{E_{0} \cos \theta / k T} d \Omega}{\int e^{E_{0} \cos \theta / k T} d \Omega} \\
& =\frac{\int_{0}^{\pi} \cos \theta e^{E_{0} \cos \theta / k T} \sin \theta d \theta}{\int_{0}^{\pi} e^{E_{0} \cos \theta / k T} \sin \theta d \theta} d q \\
& =d q\left[\operatorname{coth}\left(\frac{E_{0}}{k T}\right)-\frac{k T}{E_{0}}\right] \text {, } \\
& \bar{E}=-\bar{p} \varepsilon \text {. } \\
& \chi=\frac{\partial \bar{p}}{\partial \varepsilon}=\frac{d q}{\varepsilon} \cdot \frac{k T}{E_{0}}\left[1-\frac{\left(\frac{E_{0}}{k T}\right)^{2}}{\sinh ^{2}\left(\frac{E_{0}}{k T}\right)}\right] \text {, } \\
& c=\frac{\partial \bar{E}}{\partial T}=k\left[1-\frac{\left(\frac{E_{0}}{k T}\right)^{2}}{\sinh ^{2}\left(\frac{E_{0}}{k T}\right)}\right] \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

The condition for classical approximation to be valid is that the quantization of the rotational energy can be neglected, that is, $k T \gg \frac{\hbar^{2}}{m d^{2}}$.

Problem Statement:
The response of polar substances (e.g., $\mathrm{HCl}, \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$, etc) to applied electric fields can be described in terms of a classical model which attributes to each molecule a permanent electric dipole moment of magnitude $p$.

Calculate explicitly an approximate result for the average macroscopic polarization $\bar{p}$ at high temperatures $(K T \gg p E)$.
Solution:
The energy of a dipole in electric field is

$$
u_{e}=-\mathbf{p} \cdot E=-p E \cos \theta .
$$

The partition function is then

$$
z \approx \int_{0}^{z} e^{p E \cos \theta / k T} \sin \theta d \theta=\frac{2 k T}{p E} \sinh \left(\frac{p E}{k T}\right) .
$$

The polarization is

$$
\bar{p}=-\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial E}\right)_{V, T, N}=n k T \frac{\partial \ln z}{\partial E}=-\frac{n k T}{E}+n p \operatorname{coth} \frac{p E}{k T}
$$

Under the condition $x=\frac{p E}{k T} \ll 1, \operatorname{coth} x \approx \frac{1}{3} x+\frac{1}{x}$, and we have

$$
\bar{p} \approx n p^{2} E / 3 k T .
$$

Problem Statement:
A system of $N$ identical spinless bosons of mass $m$ is in a box of volume $V=L^{3}$ at temperature $T>0$.

Show that in the limit that the average distance, $d$, between the particles is very large compared to their de Broglie wavelength (i.e., $d \gg$ i) the distribution becomes equal to that calculated using the classical (Boltzmann) distribution function.
Solution:
The number of particles is

$$
n(\varepsilon)=\frac{2 \pi V(2 m)^{3 / 2}}{h^{3}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{\varepsilon}}{e^{(\varepsilon-\mu) / k T}-1} d \varepsilon
$$

In the approximation of a dilute gas, we have $\exp (-\mu / k T) \gg 1$, and the Bose-Einstein distribution becomes the Boltzmann distribution. We will prove as follows that this limiting condition is just $d \gg \lambda$.

Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
N &=\frac{2 \pi V(2 m)^{3 / 2}}{h^{3}} \cdot \int_{0}^{\infty} \sqrt{\varepsilon} e^{-\frac{\varepsilon}{k T}} e^{\frac{4}{k T}} d \varepsilon \\
&=V\left(\frac{2 \pi m k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} e^{\frac{4}{k T}},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
e^{-\frac{4}{k T}}=\frac{V}{N} \cdot \frac{1}{\lambda^{3}}=\left(\frac{d}{\lambda}\right)^{3},
$$

where $\lambda=h / \sqrt{2 \pi m k T}$ is the de Broglie wavelength of the particle's thermal motion, and $d=\sqrt[3]{V / N}$.

Thus the approximation $\exp (-\mu / k T) \gg 1$ is equivalent to $d \gg \lambda$.

Problem Statement:
A system of $N$ identical spinless bosons of mass $m$ is in a box of volume $V=L^{3}$ at temperature $T>0$.

Calculate the 1st order difference in average energy between a system of $N$ non-identical spinless particles and a system of $N$ identical spinless bosons when $d \gg \lambda$. For both systems the cubical box has volume $\dot{V}=L^{3}$ and the particles have mass $m$.
Solution:
The number of particles is

$$
n(\varepsilon)=\frac{2 \pi V(2 m)^{3 / 2}}{h^{3}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{\varepsilon}}{e^{(\varepsilon-\mu) / k T}-1} d \varepsilon
$$

In the approximation of a dilute gas, we have $\exp (-\mu / k T) \gg 1$, and the Bose-Einstein distribution becomes the Boltzmann distribution. We will prove as follows that this limiting condition is just $d \gg \lambda$.

Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
N &=\frac{2 \pi V(2 m)^{3 / 2}}{h^{3}} \cdot \int_{0}^{\infty} \sqrt{\varepsilon} e^{-\frac{\varepsilon}{k T}} e^{\frac{4}{k T}} d \varepsilon \\
&=V\left(\frac{2 \pi m k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} e^{\frac{4}{k T}},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
e^{-\frac{4}{k T}}=\frac{V}{N} \cdot \frac{1}{\lambda^{3}}=\left(\frac{d}{\lambda}\right)^{3},
$$

where $\lambda=h / \sqrt{2 \pi m k T}$ is the de Broglie wavelength of the particle's thermal motion, and $d=\sqrt[3]{V / N}$.

Thus the approximation $\exp (-\mu / k T) \gg 1$ is equivalent to $d \gg \lambda$.In the 1st order approximation

$$
\frac{1}{e^{(\varepsilon-\mu) k T}-1} \approx e^{-(\epsilon-\mu) / k T}\left(1+e^{-(\varepsilon-\mu) / k T}\right),
$$

the average energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{E}=& \frac{2 \pi V(2 m)^{3 / 2}}{h^{3}}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} \varepsilon \sqrt{\varepsilon} e^{\mu / k T} e^{-\varepsilon / k T} d \varepsilon\right.\\
&\left.+\int_{0}^{\infty} \varepsilon \sqrt{\varepsilon} e^{2 \mu / k T} e^{-2 \varepsilon / k T} d \varepsilon\right]=\frac{3}{2} N k T\left(1+\frac{1}{4 \sqrt{2}} \frac{\lambda^{3}}{d^{3}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
Consider a quantum-mechanical gas of non-interacting spin zero bosons, each of mass $m$ which are free to move within volume $V$.

Find the energy and heat capacity in the very low temperature region. Discuss why it is appropriate at low temperatures to put the chemical potential equal to zero.

Note: Put all integrals in dimensionless form, but do not evaluate.
Solution:
The Bose distribution

$$
\frac{1}{e^{(\varepsilon-\mu) / k T}-1}
$$

requires that $\mu \leq 0$. Generally

$$
n=\int \frac{1}{e^{(\varepsilon-\mu) / k T}-1} \cdot \frac{2 \pi}{h^{3}}(2 m)^{3 / 2} \sqrt{\varepsilon} d \varepsilon .
$$

When $T$ decreases, the chemical potential $\mu$ increases until $\mu=0$, for which

$$
n=\int \frac{1}{e^{\epsilon / k T}-1} \frac{2 \pi}{h^{3}}(2 m)^{3 / 2} \sqrt{\varepsilon} d \varepsilon .
$$

Bose condensation occurs when the temperature continues to decrease with $\mu=0$. Therefore, in the limit of very low temperatures, the Bose system can be regarded as having $\mu=0$. The number of particles at the noncondensed state is not conserved. The energy density $u$ and specific heat $c$ are thus obtained as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
u &=\int \frac{\varepsilon}{e^{\varepsilon / k T}-1} \cdot \frac{2 \pi}{h^{3}}(2 m)^{3 / 2} \sqrt{\varepsilon} d \varepsilon \\
&=\frac{2 \pi}{h^{3}}(2 m)^{3 / 2}(k T)^{3 / 2} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{3 / 2}}{e^{x}-1} d x . \\
c &=5 \pi k\left(\frac{2 m k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{3 / 2}}{e^{x}-1} d x .
\end{aligned}
$$
Final Answer: $$5 \pi k\left(\frac{2 m k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{3 / 2}}{e^{x}-1} d x$$

Problem Statement:
Consider a cubical box of side $L$ with no matter in its interior. The walls are fixed at absolute temperature $T$, and they are in thermal equilibrium with the electromagnetic radiation field in the interior.

Find the mean electromagnetic energy per unit volume in the frequency range from $\omega$ to $\omega+d \omega$ as a function of $\omega$ and $T$.
(Hint: you do not have to actually carry out the integration of the result of part (a) to answer this question.)
Solution:
The mean electromagnetic energy in the momentum interval $p \rightarrow$ $p+d p$ is given by

$$
d E_{p}=2 \cdot \frac{V}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{3}} \cdot \frac{4 \pi p^{2} d p \hbar \omega}{e^{\hbar \omega / 2 \pi k T}-1},
$$

where the factor 2 corresponds to the two polarizations of electromagnetic waves and $V=L^{3}$.

Making use of $p=\hbar \omega / c$, we obtain the mean electromagnetic energy in the frequency interval $\omega \rightarrow \omega+d \omega$ :

$$
d E_{\omega}=\frac{V \hbar}{\pi^{2} c^{3}} \frac{\omega^{3} d \omega}{e^{h \omega / 2 \pi k T}-1} .
$$

The corresponding energy density is

$$
d u_{\omega}=\frac{\hbar}{\pi^{2} c^{3}} \frac{\omega^{3} d \omega}{e^{h \omega / 2 \pi k T}-1} .
$$

Problem Statement:
Consider a cubical box of side $L$ with no matter in its interior. The walls are fixed at absolute temperature $T$, and they are in thermal equilibrium with the electromagnetic radiation field in the interior.

(If you wish to start with a known distribution function - e.g., Maxwell-Boltzmann, Planck, etc. - you need not derive that function.)

Find the temperature dependence of the total electromagnetic energy per unit volume.
(Hint: you do not have to actually carry out the integration of the result of part (a) to answer this question.)
Solution:
The mean electromagnetic energy in the momentum interval $p \rightarrow$ $p+d p$ is given by

$$
d E_{p}=2 \cdot \frac{V}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{3}} \cdot \frac{4 \pi p^{2} d p \hbar \omega}{e^{\hbar \omega / 2 \pi k T}-1},
$$

where the factor 2 corresponds to the two polarizations of electromagnetic waves and $V=L^{3}$.

Making use of $p=\hbar \omega / c$, we obtain the mean electromagnetic energy in the frequency interval $\omega \rightarrow \omega+d \omega$ :

$$
d E_{\omega}=\frac{V \hbar}{\pi^{2} c^{3}} \frac{\omega^{3} d \omega}{e^{h \omega / 2 \pi k T}-1} .
$$

The corresponding energy density is

$$
d u_{\omega}=\frac{\hbar}{\pi^{2} c^{3}} \frac{\omega^{3} d \omega}{e^{h \omega / 2 \pi k T}-1} .
$$The total electromagnetic energy per unit volume is

$$
u=\int_{0}^{\infty} d u_{\omega}=\frac{(k T)^{4}}{\pi^{2}(\hbar c)^{3}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{3} d x}{e^{x}-1} .
$$

Thus $u \propto T^{4}$.

Problem Statement:
A historic failure of classical physics is its description of the electromagnetic radiation from a black body. Consider a simple model for an ideal black body consisting of a cubic cavity of side $L$ with a small hole in one side.

Find the temperature dependence of the total power emitted from
Solution:
For a set of three positive integers $\left(n_{1}, n_{2}, n_{3}\right)$, the electromagnetic field at thermal equilibrium in the cavity has two modes of oscillation with the frequency $\nu\left(n_{1}, n_{2}, n_{3}\right)=\frac{c}{2 L}\left(n_{1}^{2}+n_{2}^{2}+n_{3}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}$. Therefore, the number of modes within the frequency interval $\Delta \nu$ is

$$
\left(\frac{4 \pi}{8} \nu^{2} \Delta \nu\right)\left(\frac{2 L}{c}\right)^{2} \cdot 2
$$

Equipartition of energy then gives an energy density

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{\nu} &=\frac{1}{L^{3}} \frac{d E}{d \nu}=\frac{1}{L^{3}} \cdot \frac{k T \cdot \frac{4 \pi}{8} \nu^{2} \Delta \nu \cdot\left(\frac{2 L}{c}\right)^{2} \cdot 2}{\Delta \nu} \\
&=8 \pi \nu^{2} k T / c^{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

When $\nu$ is very large, this expression does not agree with experimental observations since it implies $u_{\nu} \propto \nu^{2}$.

For oscillations of freqeuncy $\nu$, the average energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} n h \nu e^{-n h \nu / k T}}{\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} e^{-n h \nu / k T}}=-\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial \beta} \ln \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} e^{-\beta n h \nu}\right|_{\beta=\frac{1}{k T}} \\
&\quad=h \nu e^{-h \nu \beta} /\left(1-e^{-h \nu \beta}\right)=\frac{h \nu}{e^{h \nu \beta}-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

which is to replace the classical quantity $k T$ to give

$$
u_{\nu}=\frac{8 \pi \nu^{2}}{c^{3}} \cdot \frac{h \nu}{e^{h \nu \beta}-1} .
$$

The energy radiated from the hole per unit time is

$$
u \propto \int_{0}^{\infty} u_{\nu} d \nu \propto T^{4} .
$$

Problem Statement: Electromagnetic radiation following the Planck distribution fills a cavity of volume $V$. Initially $\omega_{i}$ is the frequency of the maximum of the curve of $u_{i}(\omega)$, the energy density per unit angular frequency versus $\omega$. If the volume is expanded quasistatically to $2 V$, what is the final peak frequency $\omega_{f}$ of the $u_{f}(\omega)$ distribution curve? The expansion is adiabatic.

the angular frequency $\omega$ which makes $u(\omega)$ extremum is $\omega=\gamma T$, where $\gamma$ is a constant. On the other hand, from $d U=T d S-p d V$ and $U=3 p V$, we obtain $V^{4} p^{3}=$ const when $d S=0$. Since $p \propto T^{4}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
V T^{3} &=\text { const., } \\
T_{f} &=\left(\frac{V_{i}}{V_{f}}\right)^{1 / 3} T_{i}=\frac{T_{i}}{3 \sqrt{2}}, \\
\omega_{f} &=\frac{\omega_{i}}{\sqrt[3]{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
As you know, the universe is pervaded by $3 \mathrm{~K}$ black body radiation. In a simple view, this radiation arose from the adiabatic expansion of a much hotter photon cloud which was produced during the big bang. isothermal?

Write down an integral which determines how much energy per cubic meter is contained in this cloud of radiation. Estimate the result within an order of magnitude in joules per (meter) ${ }^{3}$.
Solution:
The photon cloud is an isolated system, so its expansion is adiabatic.

Th energy density of black body radiation is $u=a T^{4}$, so that the total energy $E \propto V T^{4}$. From the formula $T d S=d E+p d V$, we have

$$
T\left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial T}\right)_{V}=\left(\frac{\partial E}{\partial T}\right)_{V} \propto V T^{3} .
$$

Hence $S=V T^{3}$. const.

For a reversible adiabatic expansion, the entropy $S$ remains unch anged. Thus when $V$ doubles $T$ will decrease by a factor $(2)^{-1 / 3}$. So after another $10^{10}$ years, the temperature of black body radiation will become $T=3 \mathrm{~K} / 2^{1 / 3}$.

The black body radiation obeys the Bose-Einstein Statistics:

$$
\frac{E}{V}=2 \int \frac{d^{3} p}{h^{3}} p c \frac{1}{e^{\beta p c}-1}=\frac{8 \pi c}{h^{3}} \frac{1}{(\beta c)^{4}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{2} d x}{e^{x}-1},
$$

where the factor 2 is the number of polarizations per state. Hence

$$
\frac{E}{V}=\frac{8 \pi^{5}}{15} \frac{(k T)^{4}}{(h c)^{3}}=10^{-14} \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{m}^{3} .
$$

Problem Statement:
Our universe is filled with black body radiation (photons) at a temperature $T=3 \mathrm{~K}$. This is thought to be a relic, of early developments following the "big bang".

Express the photon number density $n$ analytically in terms of $T$ and universal constants. Your answer should explicitly show the dependence on $T$ and on the universal constants. However, a certain numerical cofactor may be left in the form of a dimensionless integral which need not be evaluated at this stage.
Solution:
The Bose distribution is given by

$$
n(k)=1 /[\exp (\beta \varepsilon(k))-1] .
$$

The total number of photons is then

$$
N=2 \cdot V \int \frac{d^{3} k}{(2 \pi)^{3}} \frac{1}{e^{\beta h c k / 2 \pi}-1},
$$

where $\varepsilon(k)=h k c$ for photons and $\beta=\frac{1}{k_{B} T}$. The factor 2 is due to the two directions of polarization. Thus

$$
n=\frac{N}{V}=\frac{1}{\pi^{2}}\left(\frac{k_{B} T}{\hbar c}\right)^{3} \cdot I,
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=\int_{0}^{\infty} d x \frac{x^{2}}{e^{x}-1} \\

Problem Statement:
Our universe is filled with black body radiation (photons) at a temperature $T=3 \mathrm{~K}$. This is thought to be a relic, of early developments following the "big bang".

Now estimate the integral roughly, use your knowledge of the universal constants, and determine $n$ roughly, to within about two orders of magnitude, for $T=3 \mathrm{~K}$.
Solution:
The Bose distribution is given by

$$
n(k)=1 /[\exp (\beta \varepsilon(k))-1] .
$$

The total number of photons is then

$$
N=2 \cdot V \int \frac{d^{3} k}{(2 \pi)^{3}} \frac{1}{e^{\beta h c k / 2 \pi}-1},
$$

where $\varepsilon(k)=h k c$ for photons and $\beta=\frac{1}{k_{B} T}$. The factor 2 is due to the two directions of polarization. Thus

$$
n=\frac{N}{V}=\frac{1}{\pi^{2}}\left(\frac{k_{B} T}{\hbar c}\right)^{3} \cdot I,
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=\int_{0}^{\infty} d x \frac{x^{2}}{e^{x}-1} \\
&=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{\infty} d x \cdot x^{2} e^{-n x}=2 \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^{3}} \approx 2.4 .
\end{aligned}
$$When $T=3 \mathrm{~K}, n \approx 1000 / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$.

Problem Statement:
Imagine the universe to be a spherical cavity, with a radius of $10^{28} \mathrm{~cm}$ and impenetrable walls.

If the temperature were $0 \mathrm{~K}$, and the universe contained $10^{80}$ electrons in a Fermi distribution, calculate the Fermi momentum of the electrons.
Solution:
The number of photons in the angular frequency range from $\omega$ to $\omega+d \omega$ is

$$
d N=\frac{V}{\pi^{2} c^{3}} \frac{\omega^{2} d \omega}{e^{\beta \hbar \omega}-1}, \quad \beta=\frac{1}{k T} .
$$

The total number of photons is

$$
\begin{aligned}
N &=\frac{V}{\pi^{2} c^{3}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\omega^{2} d \omega}{e^{\beta \omega h / 2 \pi}-1}=\frac{V}{\pi^{2} c^{3}} \frac{1}{(\beta \hbar)^{3}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{2} d x}{e^{x}-1} \\
&=\frac{V}{\pi^{2}}\left(\frac{k T}{\hbar c}\right)^{3} \cdot 2 \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^{3}} \approx \frac{2 \times 1.2}{\pi^{2}} \cdot V\left(\frac{k T}{\hbar c}\right)^{3} \\
&=\frac{2.4}{\pi^{2}} \cdot \frac{4}{3} \pi \cdot\left(10^{28}\right)^{3} \cdot\left(\frac{1.38 \times 10^{-16} \times 3}{1.05 \times 10^{-27} \times 3 \times 10^{10}}\right)^{3} \\
& \approx 2.5 \times 10^{87} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The total energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=\frac{V \hbar}{\pi^{2} c^{3}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\omega^{3} d \omega}{e^{\beta \omega h / 2 \pi}-1}=\frac{\pi^{2} k^{4}}{15(h c / 2 \pi)^{3}} V T^{4} \\
& \approx 2.6 \times 10^{72} \mathrm{ergs} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The Fermi momentum of the electrons is

$$
p_{F}=\hbar\left(3 \pi^{2} \frac{N}{V}\right)^{1 / 3}=2 \times 10^{-26} \mathrm{~g} \cdot \mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{s} .
$$

Problem Statement:
If the displacement of an atom about its equilibrium position in a harmonic solid is denoted by $U$, then the average displacement squared is given by

$$
\left\langle U^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d \varepsilon}{\varepsilon} g(\varepsilon)[1+2 n(\varepsilon)],
$$

where $M$ is the mass of the atom, $g(\varepsilon)$ is a suitably normalized density of energy states and $n(\varepsilon)$ is the Bose-Einstein occupation factor for phonons of energy $\varepsilon$. Assuming a Debye model for the density of states:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
g(\varepsilon)=9 \varepsilon^{2} /\left(\hbar \omega_{D}\right)^{3} & \text { for } \varepsilon<\hbar \omega_{D} \\
g(\varepsilon)=0 & \text { for } \varepsilon>\hbar \omega_{D}
\end{array}
$$

where $\omega_{D}$ is the Debye frequency, determine the temperature dependence of $\left\langle U^{2}\right\rangle$ for very high and very low temperatures. Do your results make sense?
Solution:
For the solid we have $C_{v} \propto T^{3}$ at low temperatures and $C_{v}=$ constant at high temperatures. So it is an insulator.

The phonon is a boson. The Bose-Einstein occupation factor for phonons of energy $\varepsilon$ is

$$
n(\varepsilon)=\frac{1}{e^{c / k T}-1} .
$$

So

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle U^{2}\right\rangle &=\frac{\hbar^{3}}{2 M} \int_{0}^{h \omega_{\mathcal{D}} / 2 \pi} \frac{d \varepsilon}{\varepsilon} \frac{9 \varepsilon^{2}}{\left(\hbar \omega_{D}\right)^{3}}\left[1+\frac{2}{e^{\varepsilon / k T}-1}\right] \\
&=\frac{9 \hbar^{2}}{4 M} \cdot \frac{1}{\hbar \omega_{D}}+\frac{9 \hbar^{2}}{M} \cdot \frac{1}{\left(\hbar \omega_{D}\right)^{3}} \int_{0}^{h \omega_{D} / 2 \pi} \frac{\varepsilon}{e^{\varepsilon / k T}-1} d \varepsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the temperature is high, i.e., $k T \gg \varepsilon$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle U^{2}\right\rangle & \approx \frac{9 \hbar^{2}}{4 M} \cdot \frac{1}{\hbar \omega_{D}}+\frac{9 \hbar^{2}}{M} \cdot \frac{1}{\left(\hbar \omega_{D}\right)^{3}} \int_{0}^{h \omega_{\mathcal{D}} / 2 \pi} \varepsilon \cdot \frac{k T}{\varepsilon} d \varepsilon . \\
& \approx \frac{9 \hbar^{2}}{M} \cdot \frac{k T}{\left(\hbar \omega_{D}\right)^{2}} \propto T .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the temperature is low, i.e., $k T \ll \varepsilon$.

$$
\left\langle U^{2}\right\rangle \approx \frac{9 \hbar^{2}}{4 M} \cdot \frac{1}{\hbar \omega_{D}} .
$$

These results show that the atoms are in motion at $T=0$, and the higher the temperature the more intense is the motion.

Problem Statement:
A one dimensional lattice consists of a linear array of $N$ particles $(N \gg$ 1) interacting via spring-like nearest neighbor forces. The normal mode frequencies (radians/sec) are given by

$$
\omega_{n}=\bar{\omega} \sqrt{2(1-\cos (2 \pi n / N))} \text {, }
$$

where $\bar{\omega}$ is a constant and $n$ an integer ranging from $-N / 2$ to $+N / 2$. The system is in thermal equilibrium at temperature $T$. Let $c_{v}$ be the constant "volume" (length) specific heat.

For $T \rightarrow 0$

$$
c_{v} \rightarrow A \omega^{-\alpha} T^{\gamma},
$$

where $A$ is a constant that you need not compute. Compute the exponents $\alpha$ and $\gamma$.

The problem is to be treated quantum mechanically.
Solution:
$U=\sum_{n=-\frac{N}{2}}^{\frac{N}{2}} \hbar \omega_{n} \frac{1}{e^{n \omega_{n} / k T}-1}$.

When $k T \gg \hbar \omega_{n}$

$$
U \approx \sum \hbar \omega_{n} \cdot \frac{k T}{\hbar \omega_{n}}=N k T
$$

Hence $c_{v}=\frac{d U}{d T}=N k$.When $k T \ll \hbar \omega$, we have

$$
U=\sum_{n=-\frac{N}{2}}^{\frac{N}{3}} \hbar \omega_{n} \frac{1}{e^{\hbar \omega_{n} / k T}-1} \approx 2 \sum_{n=0}^{N / 2} \hbar \omega_{n} e^{-\hbar \omega_{n} / k T} .
$$

So

$$
c_{v}=\frac{d U}{d T}=2 \sum_{n=0}^{N / 2} \frac{\left(\hbar \omega_{n}\right)^{2}}{k T^{2}} e^{-\hbar \omega_{n} / k T} .
$$

Notice that as $N \gg 1$ we have approximately

$$
\begin{aligned}
c_{v} &=2 \frac{\hbar^{2} \omega^{2}}{k T^{2}} \int_{0}^{N / 2} 2\left(1-\cos \frac{2 \pi x}{N}\right) e^{-(h \omega / \pi k T) \sin (\pi x / N)} d x \\
&=8 \frac{\hbar^{2} \omega^{2}}{k T^{2}} \int_{0}^{N / 2} \frac{\sin ^{2} \frac{\pi x}{N} e^{-(h \omega / \pi k T) \sin (\pi x / N)}}{\cos \frac{\pi x}{N}} \cdot \frac{N}{\pi} d\left(\sin \frac{\pi x}{N}\right) \\
&=\frac{8 \hbar^{2} \omega^{2}}{k T^{2}}-\frac{N}{\pi} \int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{2} e^{-(t h \omega / \pi k T)}}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} d t .
\end{aligned}
$$

Because $\exp (-t h \omega / \pi k T)$ decreases rapidly as $t \rightarrow 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
c_{v} & \approx \frac{8 \hbar^{2} \omega^{2}}{k T^{2}} \cdot \frac{N}{\pi} \int_{0}^{1} t^{2} e^{-(t h \omega / \pi k T)} d t \\
&=\frac{8 \hbar^{2} \omega^{2}}{k T^{2}} \cdot \frac{N}{\pi} \cdot\left(\frac{k T}{\hbar \omega}\right)^{3} \cdot \int_{0}^{\infty} \xi^{2} e^{-\xi} d \xi=A \omega^{-1} T,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $A=\left(16 N k^{2} / h\right) \int_{0}^{\infty} \xi^{2} \exp (-\xi) d \xi$

Hence $\alpha=\gamma=1$.

Problem Statement:
Consider an ideal quantum gas of Fermi particles at a temperature $T$.

Find the root-mean-square fluctuation $\left\langle(n-\langle n\rangle)^{2}\right\rangle^{1 / 2}$ in the occupation number of a single particle state as a function of the mean occ upation number $\langle n\rangle$. Sketch the result.
Solution:
Let $\varepsilon$ be the energy of a single particle state, $\mu$ be the chemcial potential. The partition function is

$$
z=\sum_{n} \exp [n(\mu-\varepsilon) / k T]=1+\exp [(\mu-\varepsilon) / k T] .
$$

The mean occupation number is

$$
\langle n\rangle=k T \frac{\partial}{\partial \mu} \ln z=\frac{1}{e^{(\bullet-\mu) / k T}+1} .
$$

The probability is

$$
\begin{aligned}
p(n) &=\frac{1}{z} e^{n(\mu-\varepsilon) / k T} \\
&=\frac{(1-\langle n\rangle)^{n}}{\langle n\rangle^{n-1}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

$\left\langle(n-\langle n\rangle)^{2}\right\rangle=k T \frac{\partial\langle n\rangle}{\partial \mu}=\langle n\rangle(1-\langle n\rangle)$.

So we have $\left\langle(n-\langle n\rangle)^{2}\right\rangle^{1 / 2}=\sqrt{\langle n\rangle(1-\langle n\rangle)}$.

Problem Statement:
Suppose that in some sample the density of states of the electrons $D(\varepsilon)$ is a constant $D_{0}$ for energy $\varepsilon>0(D(\varepsilon)=0$ for $\varepsilon<0)$ and that the total number of electrons is equal to $N$.

Calculate the Fermi potential $\mu_{0}$ at $0 \mathrm{~K}$.
Solution:
When $T=0 \mathrm{~K}$, all the low lying energy levels are occupied, while those levels whose energies $\varepsilon$ are greater than $\mu_{0}$ are all vacant. Taking the $1 / 2$ spin of electrons into consideration, every state can accomodate two electrons, and hence $2 D_{0} \mu_{0} V=N$, or

$$
\mu_{0}=\frac{N}{2 V D_{0}},
$$

where $V$ is the volume of the sample.

Problem Statement:
Consider a system of $N$ "non-interacting" electrons $/ \mathrm{cm}^{3}$, each of which can occupy either a bound state with energy $\varepsilon=-E_{d}$ or a free-particle continuum with $\varepsilon=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}$.
(This could be a semiconductor like Si with $N$ shallow donors $/ \mathrm{cm}^{3}$.)

Compute the number of free electrons (i.e., electrons in the continuum) as a function of $T$ in the low temperature limit.
Solution:
Suppose that each bound state can at most contain a pair of electrons with anti-parallel spins, and that the number of bound states is $\frac{N}{2}$. That is, when $T=0 \mathrm{~K}$, all the bound states are filled up with no free electrons. When $T$ is quite low, only a few electrons are in the free particle continuum so that we can use the approximation of weak-degeneracy.

The density of states in the continuum is

$$
D(\varepsilon)=\frac{4 \pi}{h^{3}}(2 m)^{3 / 2} \sqrt{\varepsilon} .
$$The number of electrons in the bound states are

$$
N_{b}=\frac{N}{e^{-\left(E_{d}+\mu\right) / k T}+1},
$$

or

$$
\frac{N-N_{b}}{N_{b}}=e^{-E_{d} / k T} e^{-\mu / k T}
$$

The number of electrons in the continuum (weak-degeneracy approximation) is

$$
N_{f}=\int_{0}^{\infty} D(\varepsilon) e^{\mu / k T} e^{-\varepsilon / k T} d \varepsilon=N_{c} e^{\mu / k T}
$$

where

$$
N_{c}=2\left(\frac{2 \pi m k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2}
$$

From $(1)$ and $(2)$, we get

$$
\frac{N_{f}\left(N-N_{b}\right)}{N_{b}}=N_{c} e^{-E_{d} / k T} .
$$

Since $N_{b}+N_{f}=N, N_{b} \approx N$, then

$$
N_{f}^{2}=N N_{c} e^{-E_{d} / k T}, \text { or } \quad N_{f}=\sqrt{N N_{c}} e^{-E_{d} / 2 k T} .
$$

Substitute (3) in $(2)$, we get

$$
\mu=k T \ln \frac{N_{f}}{N_{c}}=\frac{k T}{2} \ln \frac{N}{N_{c}}-\frac{E_{d}}{2}
$$

Problem Statement: For a system of electrons, assumed non-interacting, show that the probability of finding an electron in a state with energy $\Delta$ above the chemical potential $\mu$ is the same as the probability of finding an electron absent from a state with energy $\Delta$ below $\mu$ at any given temperature $T$.
Solution:
pied is

By the Fermi distribution, the probability for a level $\varepsilon$ to be occu-

$$
F(\varepsilon)=\frac{1}{e^{\beta(\varepsilon-\mu)}+1},
$$

so the probability for finding an electron at $\varepsilon=\mu+\Delta$ is

$$
F(\mu+\Delta)=\frac{1}{e^{\beta \Delta}+1},
$$

and the probability for not finding electrons at $\varepsilon=\mu-\Delta$ is given by

$$
1-F(\mu-\Delta)=\frac{1}{e^{\beta \Delta+1}} .
$$

The two probabilities have the same value as required.

Problem Statement: If there is an excess of $n_{d}$ electrons per unit volume than can be accommodated by the states with $\varepsilon<0$, what is the equation for $\mu$ for $T=0$ ? How will $\mu$ shift as $T$ increases?
Solution:
pied is

By the Fermi distribution, the probability for a level $\varepsilon$ to be occu-

$$
F(\varepsilon)=\frac{1}{e^{\beta(\varepsilon-\mu)}+1},
$$

so the probability for finding an electron at $\varepsilon=\mu+\Delta$ is

$$
F(\mu+\Delta)=\frac{1}{e^{\beta \Delta}+1},
$$

and the probability for not finding electrons at $\varepsilon=\mu-\Delta$ is given by

$$
1-F(\mu-\Delta)=\frac{1}{e^{\beta \Delta+1}} .
$$

The two probabilities have the same value as required.When $T>0 \mathrm{~K}$, some electrons with $\varepsilon<0$ will be excited to states of $\varepsilon>\varepsilon_{g}$. That is to say, vacancies are produced in the some states of $\varepsilon<0$ while some electrons occupy states of $\varepsilon>\varepsilon_{g}$. The number of electrons with $\varepsilon>\varepsilon_{g}$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
n_{\mathrm{e}} &=\int_{\varepsilon_{g}}^{\infty} D(\varepsilon) \frac{1}{e^{\beta(\varepsilon-\mu)}+1} d \varepsilon \\
&=\int_{\varepsilon_{g}}^{\infty} a\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{g}\right)^{1 / 2} \frac{1}{e^{\beta(\varepsilon-\mu)}+1} d \varepsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

The number of vacancies for $\varepsilon<0$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
n_{\mathrm{p}} &=\int_{-\infty}^{0} D(\varepsilon)[1-F(\varepsilon)] d \varepsilon \\
&=\int_{-\infty}^{0} b(-\varepsilon)^{1 / 2} \frac{1}{e^{-\beta(\varepsilon-\mu)}+1} d \varepsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

By $n_{\mathrm{e}}=n_{\mathrm{p}}$, we have $\mu=\varepsilon_{g} / 2$ when $a=b$. We also obtain the equation to determine $\mu$ when $a \neq b$,

$$
\frac{a}{b}=\frac{e^{\beta\left(c+\epsilon_{g}-\mu\right)}+1}{e^{\beta(c+\mu)}+1} .
$$

For $a>b$, we have

$$
\frac{e^{\beta\left(\epsilon+\varepsilon_{g}-\mu\right)}+1}{e^{\beta(\epsilon+\mu)}+1}>1,
$$

so that $\varepsilon+\varepsilon_{g}-\mu>\varepsilon+\mu$, i.e., $\mu<\varepsilon_{g} / 2$. Hence $\mu$ shifts to lower energies. For $a\left\langle b, \mu>\varepsilon_{g} / 2, \mu\right.$ shifts to higher energies.

When $T=0$, by

$$
\int_{\varepsilon_{g}}^{\mu} a\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{g}\right)^{1 / 2} d \varepsilon=n_{d},
$$

we obtain

$$
\mu=\varepsilon_{g}+\left(\frac{3 n_{d}}{2 a}\right)^{2 / 3} .
$$

$\mu$ shifts to lower energies as $T$ increases.

Problem Statement: Derive the density of states $D(\varepsilon)$ as a function of energy $\varepsilon$ for a free electron gas in one-dimension. (Assume periodic boundary conditions or confine the linear chain to some length $L$.) Then calculate the Fermi energy $\varepsilon_{F}$ at zero temperature for an $N$ electron system.
Solution:
The energy of a particle is $\varepsilon=p^{2} / 2 m$. Thus,

$$
d p=\left(\frac{m}{2 \varepsilon}\right)^{1 / 2} d \varepsilon .
$$

Taking account of the two states of spin, we have

$$
D(\varepsilon) d \varepsilon=\frac{2 L \cdot d p}{h}=\frac{L(2 m)^{1 / 2}}{h \varepsilon^{1 / 2}} d \varepsilon,
$$

or

$$
D(\varepsilon)=L\left(\frac{2 m}{\varepsilon}\right)^{1 / 2} / h .
$$

At temperature $0 \mathrm{~K}$, the electrons will occupy all the states whose energy is from 0 to the Fermi energy $\varepsilon_{F}$. Hence

$$
N=\int_{0}^{\varepsilon_{F}} D(\varepsilon) d \varepsilon,
$$

giving

$$
\varepsilon_{F}=\frac{h^{2}}{2 m}\left(\frac{N}{2 L}\right)^{2} .
$$

Problem Statement:
Take a system of $N=2 \times 10^{22}$ electrons in a "box" of volume $V=$ $1 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$. The walls of the box are infinitely high potential barriers. Calculate the following within a factor of five and show the dependence on the relevant physical parameters:

the specific heat, $C$,
Solution:
The density of states in $\mathbf{k}$ space is given by

$$
D(k) d k=2 V \cdot \frac{4 \pi k^{2}}{8 \pi^{3}} d k,
$$

and the kinetic energy of an electron is $\varepsilon=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} k^{2}$. Combining, we get

$$
D(\varepsilon)=\frac{V}{2 \pi^{2}}\left(\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} \varepsilon^{1 / 2} .
$$

At $T=0 \mathrm{~K}$, the $N$ electrons fill up the energy levels from zero to $E_{F}=$ $\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} k_{F}^{2}$, i.e.

$$
N=\int_{0}^{E_{F}} D(\varepsilon) d \varepsilon=\frac{2}{3} D\left(E_{F}\right) E_{F}
$$

whence $E_{F}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(3 \pi^{2} \frac{N}{V}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}$.

The specific heat is

$$
C \approx k_{B}^{2} T D\left(E_{F}\right) \approx \frac{N}{E_{F}} k_{B}^{2} T,
$$

where $k_{B}$ is Boltzmann's constant.

Problem Statement:
Consider a Fermi gas model of nuclei.

Except for the Pauli principle, the nucleons in a heavy nucleus are assumed to move independently in a sphere corresponding to the nuclear volume $V$. They are considered as a completely degenerate Fermi gas. Let $A=N$ (the number of neutrons) $+Z$ (the number of protons), assume $N=$ $Z$, and compute the kinetic energy per nucleon, $E_{\text {kin }} / A$, with this model. The volume of the nucleus is given by $V=\frac{4 \pi}{3} R_{0}^{3} A, R_{0} \approx 1.4 \times 10^{-13} \mathrm{~cm}$. Please give the result in $\mathrm{MeV}$.
Solution:
In the momentum space,

$$
d n=\frac{4 V}{h^{3}} 4 \pi p^{2} d p,
$$

where $n$ is the number density of neutrons.

The total number of neutrons is

$$
\begin{aligned}
A &=\int d n=16 \pi V \int_{0}^{p_{F}} \frac{p^{2}}{h^{3}} d p \\
&=\frac{16 \pi V}{3 h^{3}} p_{F}^{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $p_{F}$ is the Fermi momentum.

The total kinetic energy of the neutrons is

$$
E_{\mathbf{k i n}}=\int \frac{p^{2}}{2 m} d n=\frac{16 \pi V}{5 h^{3}} \frac{p_{\mathrm{F}}^{5}}{2 m} .
$$

Hence,

$$
\frac{E_{\mathrm{kin}}}{A}=\frac{3}{5} \frac{p_{F}^{2}}{2 m} .
$$

The volume $V$ can be expressed in two ways:

$$
V=\frac{4 \pi}{3} R_{0}^{3} A=\frac{3(2 \pi)^{3}}{16 \pi} p_{\mathrm{F}}^{-3} A, \quad \text { (putting } \hbar \equiv \frac{h}{2 \pi}=1 \text { ) }
$$

giving $p_{F}=R_{0}^{-1}\left(\frac{9 \pi}{8}\right)^{1 / 3}$, and

$$
\frac{E_{\mathrm{kin}}}{A}=\frac{3}{10}\left(\frac{9 \pi}{8}\right)^{2 / 3} \frac{1}{m R_{0}^{2}} \approx 16 \mathrm{MeV} .
$$

Problem Statement:
A white dwarf is a star supported by the pressure of degenerate electrons. As a simplified model for such an object, consider a sphere of an ideal gas consisting of electrons and completely ionized $\mathrm{Si}^{28}$, and of constant density throughout the star.
(Note that the assumption of a constant density is inconsistent with hydrostatic equilibrium, since the pressure is then also constant. The assumption that the gas is ideal is also not really tenable. These shortcomings of the model are, however, not crucial for the issues which we wish to consider.) Let $n_{\mathrm{i}}$ denote the density of the silicon ions, and let $n_{e}=14 n_{\mathrm{i}}$ denote the electron density.
(The atomic number of silicon is 14).

Find the relation between the mean kinetic energy $\bar{E}_{\mathrm{e}}$ of the electrons and the density $n_{e}$, assuming that the densities are such that the electrons are "extremely relativistic," i.e., such that the rest energy is negligible compared with the total energy.
Solution:
Use the approximation of strong degenerate electron gas and $\varepsilon=p c$. From the quantum state density of electrons, it follows

$$
\frac{2}{h^{3}} d p=\frac{8 \pi}{h^{3} c^{3}} \varepsilon^{2} d \varepsilon,
$$

then

$$
\begin{aligned}
n_{\mathrm{e}} &=\int_{0}^{\iota \mathrm{F}} \frac{8 \pi}{h^{3} c^{3}} \varepsilon^{2} d \varepsilon \\
&=\frac{8 \pi}{3 h^{3} c^{3}} \varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}^{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore

$$
\bar{E}_{\mathrm{e}}=\frac{\int_{0}^{\epsilon_{F}} \varepsilon \cdot \varepsilon^{2} d \varepsilon}{\int_{0}^{c_{F}} \varepsilon^{2} d \varepsilon}=\frac{3}{4} \varepsilon_{F}=\frac{3}{4} h c\left(\frac{3 n_{e}}{8 \pi}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

Problem Statement: Assume that a neutron star is a highly degenerate non-relativistic gas of neutrons in a spherically symmetric equilibrium configuration. It is held together by the gravitational pull of a heavy object with mass $M$ and radius $r_{0}$ at the center of the star. Neglect all interactions among the neutrons. Calculate the neutron density as a function of the distance from the center, $r$, for $r>r_{0}$.
Solution:
For a non-relativistic degenerate gas, the density $\rho \propto \mu^{3 / 2}$, the pressure $p \propto \mu^{5 / 2}$, where $\mu$ is the chemical potential. Therefore, $p=a \rho^{5 / 3}$, where $a$ is a constant. Applying it to the equation

$$
\frac{d p}{\rho}=M G d\left(\frac{1}{r}\right)
$$

we find $a \cdot \frac{5}{2} d \rho^{2 / 3}=M G d\left(\frac{1}{r}\right)$ and hence

$$
\rho(r)=\left[\frac{2 M G}{5 a} \cdot \frac{1}{r}+\text { const }\right]^{3 / 2} .
$$

As $r \rightarrow \infty, \rho(r) \rightarrow 0$, we find const. $=0$. Finally, with $r>r_{0}$, we have

$$
\rho(r)=\left[\frac{2 M G}{5 a} \cdot \frac{1}{r}\right]^{3 / 2} .
$$

Problem Statement:
Consider a degenerate (i.e., $T=0 \mathrm{~K}$ ) gas of $N$ non-interacting electrons in a volume $V$.

Find an equation relating pressure, energy and volume of this gas for the extreme relativistic case (ignore the electron mass).
Solution:
The energy of a non-interacting degenerate electron gas is:

$$
E=8 \pi V \int_{0}^{p_{\mathrm{F}}} \frac{\varepsilon p^{2}}{h^{3}} d p
$$

where $\varepsilon$ is the energy of a single electron, $p_{F}$ is the Fermi momentum,

$$
p_{F}=(3 N / 8 \pi V)^{1 / 3} h .
$$

For the extreme relativistic case, $\varepsilon=c p$, so we have energy

$$
E=\frac{2 \pi c V}{h^{3}} p_{F}^{4},
$$

and pressure $p=-\left(\frac{\partial E}{\partial V}\right)_{T=0}=\frac{1}{3} \frac{E}{V}$, which gives the equation of state

$$
p V=\frac{1}{3} E .
$$

Problem Statement:

For a gas of real electrons (i.e., of mass $m$ ), find the condition on $N$ and $V$ for the result of part (a) to be approximately valid.
Solution:
The energy of a non-interacting degenerate electron gas is:

$$
E=8 \pi V \int_{0}^{p_{\mathrm{F}}} \frac{\varepsilon p^{2}}{h^{3}} d p
$$

where $\varepsilon$ is the energy of a single electron, $p_{F}$ is the Fermi momentum,

$$
p_{F}=(3 N / 8 \pi V)^{1 / 3} h .
$$

For the extreme relativistic case, $\varepsilon=c p$, so we have energy

$$
E=\frac{2 \pi c V}{h^{3}} p_{F}^{4},
$$

and pressure $p=-\left(\frac{\partial E}{\partial V}\right)_{T=0}=\frac{1}{3} \frac{E}{V}$, which gives the equation of state

$$
p V=\frac{1}{3} E .
$$For a real electron,

$$
\varepsilon=\sqrt{\left(m c^{2}\right)^{2}+(p c)^{2}} \approx p c\left[1+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m c}{p}\right)^{2}\right] \text {, }
$$

where $p$ is its momentum, giving

$$

$$

$$

Problem Statement:

Problem Statement:

Solution:
For a chemical reaction $\mathrm{A} \leftrightarrow \mathrm{B}+\mathrm{C}$ at equilibrium, $\mu_{\mathrm{A}}=\mu_{\mathrm{B}}+\mu_{\mathrm{C}}$. As the chemical potential of the photon gas $\mu_{\gamma}=0$, we obtain

$$
\mu_{\mathrm{e}^{+}}+\mu_{\mathrm{e}^{-}}=0 .
$$

Considering the symmetry between particle and antiparticle, we have

$$
\mu_{\mathrm{e}^{+}}=\mu_{\mathrm{e}^{-}} .
$$

Hence $\mu_{\mathrm{e}+}=\mu_{\mathrm{e}^{-}}=0$.At the limit $k T \gg m_{e} c^{2}$, neglecting the electron mass and letting $E=c p$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
N_{\mathrm{e}^{-}} &=\frac{2 V}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{3}} \int d^{3} p \frac{1}{e^{\beta c p}+1} \\
&=\frac{V}{\pi^{2}} \frac{(k T)^{3}}{(\hbar c)^{3}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{2} d x}{e^{x}+1}=N_{\mathrm{e}^{+}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

At the limit $k T \ll m_{\mathrm{e}} c^{2}$, the "1" in denominator of the Fermi factor

$$
\frac{1}{\left\lceil\exp \left(\beta \sqrt{(c p)^{2}+\left(m_{\mathrm{e}} c^{2}\right)^{2}}\right)+1\right]}
$$

can be neglected and we also have

$$
\varepsilon_{p} \equiv \sqrt{(c p)^{2}+\left(m_{\mathrm{e}} c^{2}\right)^{2}} \approx m_{\mathrm{e}} c^{2}+p^{2} / 2 m .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
N_{\mathrm{e}^{\pm}} &=\frac{2 V}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{3}} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\beta m_{\mathrm{e}} c^{2}} e^{-\beta p^{2} / 2 m_{\mathrm{e}}} 4 \pi p^{2} d p \\
&=2 V\left(\frac{2 \pi m_{\mathrm{e}} k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} e^{-m_{\mathrm{e}} c^{2} / k T} .
\end{aligned}
$$
Final Answer: $$2 V\left(\frac{2 \pi m_{\mathrm{e}} k T}{h^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} e^{-m_{\mathrm{e}} c^{2} / k T}$$

Problem Statement:
In the very early stages of the universe, it is usually a good approximation to neglect particle masses and chemical potential compared with $k T$.

(You need not evaluate dimensionless integrals of order 1.)

If the gas expands adiabatically while remaining in equilibrium, how do the average number and energy densities depend on the dimensions of the system?
Solution:
In the stated approximation, we have

$$
\varepsilon=p c, \quad \frac{\mu}{k T} \approx 0 .
$$

So

$$
N=\frac{V}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{3}} 4 \pi \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{p^{2}}{e^{p c / k T}+1} d p .
$$

The average number density is

$$
n=\frac{1}{2 \pi^{2}}\left(\frac{k T}{\hbar c}\right)^{3} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{2} d x}{e^{x}+1} .
$$

The average energy density is

$$
\rho=\frac{1}{2 \pi^{2}}\left(\frac{k T}{\hbar c}\right)^{3} k T \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{3} d x}{e^{x}+1} .
$$

The quasi-static adiabatic expansion process satisfies the equation $d(\rho V)=-p d V$. Neglecting the particle mass, we have $p=\rho / 3$ (analogous to a photon gas), then

$$
\frac{d \rho}{\rho}=-\frac{4}{3} \frac{d V}{V},
$$

giving

$$
\rho \propto V^{-4 / 3} \text {, }
$$

from which we obtain $T \propto V^{-1 / 3}$. Hence the particle number density $n \propto V^{-1}$.

Problem Statement: Consider a classical system that has two discrete total energy states $E_{0}$ and $E_{1}$. Find $Z$ and $c_{v}$.
Solution:
$F=U-T S, Z=\int \exp (-\beta E(p, q)) d \omega$, where $U$ is the internal energy, $T$ the absolute temperature, $S$ the entropy, $\beta=1 / k T, E(p, q)$ the energy of the system and $d \omega=d p d q$ an infinitesimal volume element in the phase space, $p$ and $q$ being the generalized momentum and coordinate respectively, and $k$ Boltzmann's constant.

The relation between $F$ and $Z$ is

$$
F=-k T \ln Z .
$$

From $d F=-S d T-p d V$, we have

$$
S=-\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial T}\right)_{V} .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
c_{v} &=T\left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial T}\right)_{V}=-T\left(\frac{\partial^{2} F}{\partial T^{2}}\right)_{V} \\
&=k T\left[\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial T^{2}}(T \ln Z)\right]_{V} .
\end{aligned}
$$

$Z=e^{-\beta E_{0}}+e^{-\beta E_{1}}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
c_{v} &=k T\left\{\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial T^{2}}\left[T \ln \left(e^{-\beta E_{0}}+e^{-\beta E_{1}}\right)\right]\right\}_{V} \\
&=\frac{\left(E_{1}-E_{0}\right)^{2}}{4 k T^{2} \cosh ^{2}\left(\frac{E_{1}-E_{0}}{2 k T}\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement: Find a relation between the heat capacity of a system and $\frac{\partial^{2} \ln z}{\partial \beta^{2}}$, where $\beta=\frac{1}{k T}$.
Solution:
The partition function is the sum of statistical probabilities.

For quantum statistics, $z=\sum_{s} \exp \left(-\beta E_{s}\right)$, summing over all the quantum states.

For classical statistics, $z=\int \exp (-\beta E) d \Gamma / h^{\gamma}$, integrating over the phase-space where $\gamma$ is the number of degrees of freedom.

$$
\bar{E}=-\frac{\partial}{\partial \beta} \ln z,
$$

$$
c_{v}=\frac{\partial \bar{E}}{\partial T}=-\frac{1}{k \beta^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial \beta} \bar{E}=\frac{1}{k \beta^{2}} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \beta^{2}} \ln z .
$$

Express your answer as functions of the volume $V$, temperature $T$, and number of particle $N$.
Solution:
Let $z$ denote the partition function of a single particle, $Z$ the total partition function, $p$ the pressure, $S$ the entropy, $U$ the internal energy, and $c$ the specific heat. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
z &=\frac{4 \pi V}{h^{3} c^{3}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \varepsilon^{2} e^{-\varepsilon / k T} d \varepsilon=\frac{8 \pi V}{h^{3} c^{3}}(k T)^{3} . \\
Z &=\frac{z^{N}}{N !}=\frac{1}{N !}\left(\frac{8 \pi V}{h^{3} c^{3}}\right)^{N}(k T)^{3 N} . \\
p &=\frac{1}{\beta} \frac{\partial}{\partial V} \ln Z=\frac{N}{\beta V}=\frac{N k T}{V} . \\
S &=k\left(\ln Z-\beta \frac{\partial}{\partial \beta} \ln Z\right) \\
&=N k\left(3 \ln k T+\ln \frac{8 \pi V}{N h^{3} c^{3}}+4\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
u &=-\frac{\partial}{\partial \beta} \ln Z=3 N k T \\
c &=3 N k
\end{aligned}
$$
